A lot of twists and deaths. I feel like:
As a film\, this is a solid 3/5 (cut 20 mins of pointless filler and you have a 4). However\, as a Star Wars film\, it's barely a 2/5. Finally\, as a continuation of the trilogy\, it remains to be seen what this film is. It was subversive and bold\, but that is not what audiences come to Star Wars for. This film is the one trick shot where Daffy Duck blows himself up in a spectacular stunt and says "I can only do it once."

As one professional critic who actually loved the film said\, "It's the gazillion-dollared\, 152-minute equivalent to setting fire to all of your childhood Star Wars toys in the backyard\, and getting high off the fumes that follow." This is not just true of the orginal trilogy\, The Last Jedi pretty much tosses asside the set up handed to it\, figuratively and literally (Luke and that lightsaber)\, by The Force Awakens.

The episode 9 will decide how this one ages. If the decisions here can spawn a rebirth that makes a real connection with the audience \, while possibly repenting of the heresy we witnessed\, Star Wars will be better than ever. If not\, well\, then The Force Awakens in the end of canon as far as I am concerned.
